['97
NIGHTLIFE
NIGHTLIFE
Thessaloniki is well known 
for the intense nightlife and 
the diverse options offered 
to visitors. Some say that 
this is the greek ‘capital’ of 
entertainment as many trends 
and new fashions spread 
out from this town in the 
last decades and were later 
adopted across the country. 
Ranking high in the list of 
options are the numerous bars 
(most of them with an avant-
garde design), tavernas, ouzo 
restaurants (called ouzeri), 
modern cuisine restaurants, 
clubs with live greek music, 
particularly those playing 
rebetiko - a typical genre of 
greek popular music which 
grew to new heights in this 
town – seaside bars and music 
stages. 
In the city centre, Ladadika 
(see p. 18) has been a 
favourite nightlife area 
since the early 1990s; the 
neighbouring Kalapothaki 
Street (see p. 17), the cafés 
and bars by the old beachfront 
(see p. 16) and the modern 
restaurants and bars housed 
in the historic city arcades all 
add to the picture. Worthy of 
notice are also the tavernas in 
the traditional town market 
places (see p. 21), the bars and 
the cosy, elegant restaurants 
lining the bustling city streets 
(see p. 27), as well as the area 
between Zefxidos and Iktinou 
Streets (see p. 28).', '82
Thessaloniki lies in the 
centre of a wide area that is 
extremely interesting from  
an archaeological, historical 
and natural point of view; 
there are countless options for 
outdoor activities, relaxing and 
entertainment. For instance, 
you can combine your stay 
in town with a day excursion 
to renowned archaeological 
sites and places of historical 
interest, to fascinating towns 
and great natural reserves  
or to areas offering recreation 
or relaxation.
1
	
ANCIENT PELLA
Inhabited since the Late 
Helladic period, the area 
flourished when Archelaos,  
the Macedon king, moved  
the capital of the Macedonian 
state from Aiges (Vergina) to 
Pella (late 5th – early 4th c. BC). 
The then seaside town grew 
larger during the reign of King 
Philip II (his son, Alexander 
the Great, was born here) 
and grew even larger later 
during the rule of Cassander. 
By the mid-2nd century BC it 
had evolved into the greatest 
political, financial and cultural 
centre among the Hellenic City 
States. In 168 BC when the 
Macedonians were defeated in 
the battle of Pydna, Pella was 
conquered by the Romans. 
It gradually declined and got 
eventually deserted in the 1st 
century BC. Among the finds 
of the greatest value are the 
exquisite mosaic floors in the 
buildings, which manifest the 
high standard of living enjoyed 
by the residents.
MUST SEE:
Houses.']
reference_contexts: ['The historic center of Thessaloniki features traditional commercial areas like Vlali Square, known for coffee shops and restaurants, and a memorial for MP Gr. Lamprakis. The Vatikioti market and Athonos Square offer shops selling produce, spices, and various goods, along with tavernas and ouzo restaurants. Bezesteni, a rectangular building from the late 15th century, serves as a textile and jewelry market with over 110 shops. Stoa Saul, completed in 1881 and rebuilt after a fire, combines neo-renaissance and art deco styles and is now an entertainment venue. Vas. Irakleiou, formerly known as Fragkomachalas, has transformed from a banking area to a commercial and entertainment hub, with popular tavernas and traditional marketplaces offering high-quality foodstuffs.', 'The input consists of the number 112 repeated twice.', 'The text describes notable landmarks in Thessaloniki, including the OTE Tower, built in 1969, which serves as a telecommunications hub and features a rotating café with stunning views. It also mentions the Alexandreio Melathron, a historic sports arena constructed in 1966, which has hosted various significant events and is now home to the Aris basketball team. Additionally, Angelaki Street is highlighted for its vibrant cafés and bars popular among university students, as well as the presence of several radio stations. The area surrounding the 3rd Army Corps is also noted, with its historical significance and architectural features.', 'Kalochori, located 5 km west of the city center, is a rapidly growing residential suburb known for its industrial character and local tavernas. The Gallikos River runs along its west edge, offering facilities for picnicking and relaxation. The river delta and Kalochori lagoon are home to diverse wildlife, including herons and flamingoes. The surrounding wetland area, protected by the Ramsar Convention, is part of the Natura 2000 network and offers free tours. Sindos, situated about 9 km northwest of Kalochori, has grown significantly due to the Thessaloniki Industrial Park.', 'The area features historical sites, including a World War II gun emplacement, and is home to diverse salt marshes and wetlands that shelter 178 bird species like flamingoes and cormorants. To reach the location, take the 71 or 71A bus from the Railway Station Stop to N. Michaniona, or use bus lines 02 and 02A to A.S. IKEA station and then transfer to buses 72, 72A, or 72B. If driving, follow Ethinikis Antistasis, Georgikis Scholis, and Michanionas avenues.', "The text describes various museums in Thessaloniki, Greece, including a cinema museum showcasing projectors and films from 1910, a photography museum founded in 1997 with over 100,000 photographic objects from 1890-1980, and the Olympic Museum, which focuses on Olympic and Paralympic memorabilia. Additionally, it mentions the 'Christos Tsiggiridis' Radio Museum, featuring equipment from the founder of the first radio station in the Balkans. Each museum hosts educational programs and temporary exhibitions, contributing to the cultural landscape of the city.", 'The Jewish quarter in Europe retains its traditional character, featuring Roman, Ottoman, and Industrial age monuments in districts like Kyriotissa, Panagia Dexia, and Makariotissa. The city also features a range of cultural institutions, including the State Museum of Contemporary Art and the Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki.', "The text describes several museums in Thessaloniki, including a Holocaust exhibition that memorializes the local Jewish community, particularly the 49,000 members sent to concentration camps. Lastly, the Ataturk Museum displays exhibits across two floors, highlighting the life and legacy of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk.", "The text describes notable Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki, including Agios Panteleimonas Church, which was originally part of a monastery and later converted into a mosque, featuring murals from the 13th-14th centuries. The church contains significant mosaics and a basement Krypt, believed to be the site of Saint Demetrius's martyrdom, and has been used for cultural events since 1988.", 'Ano Poli, or Old Town, features notable areas like Tsinari, Terpsithea Square, and Romfei Square. Ancient Pella, once the capital of Macedon, thrived under King Philip II and became a major cultural center before its decline after Roman conquest. The avenue is also home to several notable landmarks, including various mansions and the State Orchestra of Thessaloniki.", 'The document outlines a guide to Thessaloniki, including its history, various walking tours of the city, information on museums, day excursions, nightlife, gastronomy, and tips for touring with children.', 'The text describes the historical significance of various structures in ancient Macedonia, including a palace with a peristyle, a monumental gateway, and a temple dedicated to Hercules. Families can enjoy various fun activities and games throughout the city.", "The Lazare church in Paris, once a hospital and refugee center, was declared a historic monument in 1980 and renovated in 1997 for cultural events in Thessaloniki. Additionally, the Stavroupoli Botanical Garden spans 0.5 hectares, showcasing over 1000 plant species and providing recreational facilities. The Serbian monument is located in the Zeitenlik allied military cemetery.", 'The number 114 is repeated twice.', "Eleftherias Square, located near the harbor, served as a parking lot and was the site where 50,000 Jewish residents were gathered by German forces in 1943. The port area is one of the largest in the southeastern Mediterranean, with a rich history dating back to Constantine the Great's time.", "The Orphanos Church, built in the 1310s as part of Vlatadon Monastery, features exquisite 14th-century murals and is one of Thessaloniki's best-preserved monuments. The city walls of Thessaloniki were established shortly after its founding and underwent significant changes under Theodosius I in 390 AD. Over the centuries, the walls were reinforced during Venetian and Turkish rule, resulting in a total length of 7 km, with only 3 km remaining today. The walls are notable for their impressive height and width, contributing to their archaeological and cultural significance. For a comprehensive understanding of Byzantine art in the city, visitors are encouraged to explore the Museum of Byzantine Culture.", "Greece, a parliamentary republic and EU member since 1981, has a population of approximately 10.8 million. This museum also has a collection of contemporary Greek art and hosts temporary exhibitions.", 'The historic centre of Thessaloniki, particularly the Ladadika area, has transformed from a downgraded region post-WWII to a vibrant hotspot filled with restaurants, clubs, and live music venues since the 1990s. Key starting points for exploration include Morichovou square and Petrakaki square, where notable sights like the Ottoman Post Office Mansion can be found. Visitors can find a variety of goods, including food, clothing, and antiques, at reasonable prices. Notable shopping spots include Bit-Pazar for second-hand items and the Mediterranean Cosmos Mall, which features over 200 shops and entertainment options. Other popular areas include the Hirsch Building Mall and Plateia Mall. For budget-friendly shopping, Venizelou St., Egnatia St., and Agiou Dimitriou St. are recommended. Visitors can reach Dion via national roads or local buses from Katerini. It includes explanatory texts and photographs. Additionally, touch screens display a glossary of viticulture and wine-making terms. Room B showcases the historical significance of wine through tools and vessels, along with scenes from films and photos related to wine production and consumption.', "The text describes significant Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki, including the UNESCO-listed church that was once a cathedral and later converted into a mosque, showcasing impressive mosaics and murals. Pikionis, was constructed from 1936 to 1938.", "The phrase 'Follow Greece Everywhere' suggests a strong interest or commitment to exploring and engaging with Greek culture, history, and lifestyle in various contexts.", "Thessaloniki has a rich history marked by the settlement of various communities, particularly from the Iberian Peninsula, and a period of harmony among ethnic groups from the 16th to 18th centuries. The city evolved into a significant trade center by the 18th century and became more cosmopolitan with railway connections established in the late 19th century. Major events include a devastating fire in 1890, the Greek army's seizure of the city in 1912 after five centuries of Ottoman rule, and a significant fire in 1917 that led to extensive rebuilding. The German occupation in 1943 resulted in the tragic loss of a large portion of the Jewish population. Thessaloniki experienced a severe earthquake in 1978, and later, in 1997 and 2014, it was recognized as the European Capital of Culture and the European Youth Capital, respectively.", 'The Macedonian Museum of Contemporary Art features a permanent collection of 1,800 works by notable Greek and foreign artists and has hosted over 100 exhibitions. The publication is not for sale and is available through the Greek National Tourism Organisation's website.", 'Asprovalta and Nea Vrasna beaches offer marine sports and beach volleyball facilities, with Asprovalta beach being 10 km long and awarded a Blue Flag. It now functions as a municipal exhibition area with a collection of Roman and Early Christian sculptures. The Hatzimisef Villa, located on Vas. Olgas Ave., was the town's first high school, while the Joseph Modiano villa nearby is currently uninhabited. A bust of King George I, assassinated in 1913, stands at the corner of Vas. Olgas Ave. and Agias Triadas St., crafted by K. Dimitriadis in 1915. The Ivan Hatzimisef Villa, built in 1897, now hosts cultural events and an organic food market. The Customs House, built in 1910, serves as the city's passenger board station and showcases early 20th-century French architectural influence. The exhibition also features private collections, including the D. Papastratos Collection with religious art and the D. Oikonomopoulos Collection with a diverse range of artworks. Notable displays include exceptional gold craftsmanship from cemeteries, a reconstruction of an archaic temple, and unique items like the Derveni papyrus. The museum highlights the region's rich cultural heritage and its transition through various historical periods.", "Thessaloniki hosts several cultural institutions, including museums and galleries showcasing Greek art. The Gallery of the Society for Macedonian Studies is the city's first visual arts museum, displaying 300 pieces from major 20th-century art movements. The Cultural Centre of Thessaloniki organizes exhibitions in collaboration with local agencies, featuring around 250 pieces of various art forms. The Thessaloniki Cinema Museum, established in 1997, highlights the history of Greek cinema through exhibits categorized into six timelines.", "The text describes various historical and cultural sites in Thessaloniki, including the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the remnants of the city's west walls, particularly the Litaia Gate. The Moni Lazariston complex houses the State Museum of Contemporary Art, showcasing the area's cultural evolution.", 'The text provides contact information and websites for various museums and cultural institutions in Thessaloniki, including the Thessaloniki Cinema Museum, Museum of Photography, Olympic Museum, and more. Additionally, it mentions a collaboration among five museums in Thessaloniki aimed at promoting cultural activities and organizing exhibitions. This collaboration includes the Archaeological Museum, Museum of Byzantine Culture, State Museum of Contemporary Art, Macedonian Museum of Modern Art, and the Teloglion Foundation of Art.', 'The text describes various historical and architectural sites in Thessaloniki, including the Jewish Museum housed in a 1904 building, Venizelou Street known for its eclectic and art deco styles, and the Pazar (Yahudi) Hamami, a 16th-century bathhouse. It highlights the architectural significance of the Gategno-Florentin Building and the Chamber of Commerce & Industry, showcasing neoclassical design. The area is also noted for its vibrant marketplace, including an open-air flower market known as Louloudadika.', 'The text describes two significant Byzantine monuments in the city. The first is the Moni Latomou, an early cross-in-square domed church from the 5th or 6th century, notable for its ceiling mosaics depicting the Vision of Ezekiel and a minaret entrance from its later conversion to a mosque. The second is Moni Vlatadon, the only active Byzantine monastery in the city, founded in the 14th century, featuring a unique church structure and significant murals from the 14th and 17th centuries. It also has a large garden with views of the city and additional facilities like a library and a bookstore.', 'Thessaloniki is a city in Greece known for its rich history, vibrant culture, and significant role in the Byzantine Empire.', 'The text describes the historical development of the area known as Nea Paralia in Thessaloniki, which began to grow in the late 19th century after the demolition of city walls and the introduction of tramways. However, from the 1930s, the area declined and transformed into a typical urban setting by the 1960s. Today, Nea Paralia stretches along Megalou Alexandrou Avenue and is popular for leisure activities, offering scenic views of the Thermaic Gulf and Mount Olympus, especially at sunset. Notable landmarks include the statue of Alexander the Great and the artistic installation of umbrellas by N. Zongolopoulos.', "Thessaloniki, an early center of Christianity, was significant during the Byzantine period, housing numerous Christian monuments and churches. These structures, built between the 4th and 15th centuries, have been recognized as UNESCO World Heritage Monuments since 1988. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, one of the oldest, was constructed between 1310 and 1314 and served as the main church of a monastery. The church features murals and iconography depicting the life of the Holy Virgin. A tour of Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments offers a unique experience, showcasing the city's rich historical and cultural heritage.", 'The text describes various notable locations in Ano Poli, Thessaloniki. Tsitsani Square features a bust of composer V. Tsitsanis and is surrounded by well-tended houses. Eptapyrgiou Street runs along the northern city walls, showcasing traditional buildings and the old Zihne Camii mosque. Moni Vlatadon is mentioned as a point of interest. Portara is one of the main gates of the northern city walls, adorned with ceramics and inscriptions. The Acropolis, specifically Eptapyrgio (Yedi Kule), is highlighted as a significant fortified area within the city walls. The area is popular among both residents and tourists.', 'The text provides information about various churches in Thessaloniki, including their addresses and contact numbers. It also highlights cultural events such as Demetria, an autumn festival featuring theatrical and musical performances, and the Thessaloniki International Film Festival, which has been held since 1960 and showcases films from various sections. Additionally, it mentions the Thessaloniki International Fair (T.I.F.), a significant trade fair in the Balkans that has been taking place since 1926, presenting Greek industry and entrepreneurship. Contact information for cultural offices and event organizations is also included.', "Thessaloniki was founded in 315 BC by Cassander, named after his wife, and became a significant city under Roman control by 168 BC. It served as the capital of the Roman province of Macedonia by 148 BC and was connected to the wider world through the Via Egnatia around 130 BC. The city was declared a 'free town' in 42 BC and hosted Apostle Paul's visits. In the late 3rd to early 4th century AD, it became the seat of the eastern Roman Empire under Galerius. The city faced various raids but was protected by its walls. It experienced a golden age from 1300 to 1430, marked by cultural and economic growth. Thessaloniki changed hands multiple times, falling to the Venetians in 1423 and the Ottoman Turks in 1430, while also having a significant Jewish population in the 15th century."]

There are many restaurants in the historic centre that offer a range of traditional Greek cuisine. The city is also home to a number of historic sites, including the ancient city of Pella, which is located just a few hours outside the city.

Thessaloniki's historic centre is also home to a number of cultural attractions, including the Museum of Byzantine Culture and the Archaeological Museum. 

Overall, Thessaloniki is a great destination for anyone looking to experience the city's rich history and culture. The city's public transportation system, pedestrian-friendly streets, and range of restaurants and landmarks make it easy to get around and experience the city's best attractions.
